Author: JediGeek

Comment: Curious case for me. From a purely legal standpoint, other than the minor traffic infractions, did they actually do anything illegal?  I completely agree that it smells more than fishy and likely they were up to no good, but devil's advocate says if traveling with a lot of ammo isn't illegal then it shouldn't be an issue. If they thought these guys were planning on smuggling it across the border, why not just track them until they do try to cross the border and bust them there (where it probably is illegal to cross with weapons / ammo)?  I'm just hyper conscious that the government loves to use a valid earlier case as the precedent to do the same action against people later that isn't valid.

Author: ChristopherRoberto

Comment: 18 U.S.C. § 922 prohibits certain people, including non-citizens, from possessing firearms or ammunition. Specifically, it prohibits non-citizens who are "illegally or unlawfully in the United States" from possessing these items. Additionally, non-citizens who are "admitted to the United States under a nonimmigrant visa" are also prohibited from shipping, transporting, possessing, or receiving firearms or ammunition that has a connection to interstate commerce.
